meeting_annotations.speaker: Irene Yang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, that's that's so fascinating, Annika. Is there a relationship between that and circadian rhythms?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so we're that's something that I'm really intrigued by. So I in my postdoc lab I focused on circadian rhythms of locomotor behavior. And in flies, um they're what are called crepuscular. So they're most active at dawn and dusk. Um, and their locomotor behavior is very similar across background strains of flies. They all have a peak of activity in the morning and a peak of activity in the evening. Um, and I got really interested in investigating feeding rhythms, which is something newer in flies because we haven't really had the resolution to look at single fly feeding until more recently. Um, and so when I started to look at feeding, I thought that their feeding patterns would follow their locomotor activity, that they would eat the most when they were walking up, walking around, being awake the most. Um, and I thought that when I looked at classic circadian locomotor rhythm mutants that I would see the same deficits in their feeding rhythms. And what I found is that for flies, um locomotor activity and feeding rhythms are very decoupled.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, and to answer Jody's questions from the chat. Um, so humans are pretty terrible about how many hours a day they intake food. Um, actually, um, a couple of studies that have, well, they looked at largely undergraduate and graduate student populations. So I'm not sure how representative their food intake patterns are, probably amongst the worst, but um, they had they had students that wore um like essentially fitbits and then there was a button on their fitbit that they could press every time they put food in their mouth. So it was it was a really like they weren't trying to get them to log every meal. It was just like when you start eating press the button, when you stop eating press the button again. Um, and they found that on average in a cohort of thousands of students, people were eating 14 to 16 hours a day. Um, and um, so like between their first meal and their last meal, they were eating up to about 16 out of 24 hours. Um, and there's quite a lot of data that shows that restricting your feeding window to 10 hours or less per day is very beneficial for your health. Um, and so, you know, 16 hours is a pretty pretty broad window. Um, and and outside of the window of what most animals would eat um that are not humans. But most animals don't have insomnia cookies. Um, and they deliver till till 2:00 a.m. you guys. Just want you to know.
